Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.It#s a family affair for leboat crew membersA Campbeltown family can celebrate the proud fact that four generations have served on the crew of the town#s RNLI leboats.And two of them have both received the Royal National Leboat Institute#s bronze medal.Mark Scally, now aged , has just joined the crew at the leboat station, and he joins brothers Greg, , and Stephen, . Their father Stephen, aged , is in his th year of service with the crew.His father Robert is now aged  and, before retiring, he served  years and his father, the late Robert Scally senior, served for  years.The sea is in the Scally family blood Stephen senior, who is also the Campbeltown harbour master, was a fisherman, as was his father.#My grandfather was a fisherman and he met my grandmother at Mallaig, where she was one of the herring lasses who followed the fishing fleet as it followed the herring around the coast,# said Stephen senior. #Her family came from Peterhead and all her brothers were fishermen.#None of the latest generation of Scallys to serve is a fisherman.Between them, the Scally family have served on Campbeltown leboats City of Glasgow, City of Glasgow II, Walter and Margaret Cooper and Ernest and Mary Shaw.Stephen Scally senior and Robert Scally are both recipients of the institute#s bronze medal for bravery and both are qualied coxswains.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOGerman giant to call in the Wee ToonGermany#s flagship passenger cruise ship is to visit Campbeltown next summer with up to  passengers on board, it was revealed this week.The Hamburg-based MS Europa will be docking in the town for six hours on Wednesday July  next year, during a voyage around the British Isles.The cruiser, owned by German shipping firm Hapag-Lloyd, is  metres high and nearly  metres long.It carries between  and  passengers.It will dock in the loch around midday and leave for Oban at pm. Campbeltown Harbour Office said that the Europa was #arguably the biggest boat to come into Campbeltown for a long time#.The chairperson of Campbeltown Community Council, Mrs Nancie Smith, hoped a special gala day could be organised to mark the ship#s visit.She said: #This is an opportunity we should grasp with both hands. I anticipate there will be some form of civic entertainment laid on.#Mrs Smith added that she hoped many shops in the centre of town would not close for the half day to make the visitors feel welcome.She told the Courier: #It is important that the visitors see the town looking at its best and we hope this will be supported by all the businesses and shops which will stay open for business that day.#The local director of Argyll, the Isles, Loch Lomond, Stirling and the Trossachs Tourist Board, Mr Bruce Urquhart, hailed the Europa#s planned visit as a great opportunity for Campbeltown.FIFTY YEARS AGOFarmer#s heroic effort to save barnFire dealt a cruel blow to a local farmer yesterday afternoon, for the second time in three years.As fire fighting units raced from Campbeltown, a barn at Low Tirfergus Farm near Drumlemble was ablaze from end to end. Flames were fanned by a fresh easterly breeze.And despite a heroic effort by the farmer, Mr Roderick Morrison, son-in-law of the farm#s owner Mr A Barker, the fire had a firm hold by the time the fire brigade arrived.The alarm was raised by Mr Morrison#s we who alerted him.Armed with a pitchfork, Mr Morrison tried to separate the blazing straw, which was being used as feeding, from the rest of the barn#s contents, but it was in vain.Firemen had to jump clear as the roof caved in with a tremendous crash.The straw inside the barn was totally destroyed.The £ barn was erected three years ago after  tons of hay and  tons of straw were destroyed in a blaze at the same farm.It stood on its own, some distance from the other farm buildings.Labour back in control – by one seatLabour retained control of Campbeltown Town Council at Tuesday#s municipal elections, though they lost one seat to the Progressives.The composition of the council now reads: Labour nine seats, Progressive eight seats.Provost Daniel McKinven and Councillor Edward Scragg, who formerly sat under the Independent Socialist and SBP banners respectively, fought the contest as Progressives. Both were re-elected.And -year old William Crossan, of Kinloch Road, Campbeltown, became the youngest member ever to sit in the council chambers.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOCoal strikeAttention should be paid to the announcement in our advt. columns regarding the pressure of gas from the local works, special arrangements commencing on Saturday night with the object of conserving the stock of coal.A coal laden schooner, carrying about  tons of household coal, which arrived here just at the beginning of the coal strike and was prohibited from discharging by the customs authorities, had the embargo removed this week, the cargo being transferred to one of the local coal merchants.One hundred tons dished out in half-cwt lots, which is the household allowance for a week, will help a bit to keep the home fires burning.The coal fight drags on without the smallest sign of either side giving way. Apparently the nation will have to suffer much more before a settlement is reached, and unfortunately there is no very clear guarantee that even a settlement of the coal dispute would restore us to anything like prosperity.Every minute of the clock-round stocks are being reduced, andthe dispute lasts much longer, the miners will produce a general lock-out of their fellow-workers, which will have all the dire effects of a general strike without any of its heroics. It is a deplorable situation.

story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  At the start of the pandemic in March we took the decision to make online access to our news free of charge by taking down our paywall. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.I have been contacted by a number of my justiably concerned constituents about the recent removal of a cattle grid on the Isle of Gigha, from the road between the ferry jetty and the village.The space has been tarred over but I have been informed by residents that unfortunately the sub surface area was just grit and so the tar has subsided due to traffic including tractors and lorries. The dip now is actually worse than when the cattle grid was in place.To make matters worse, the damaged cattle grid, which is now mangled metal, has been left on the adjacent roadside verge.It is my strong belief thatcattle grids are damaged, the roads department should replace them with new fit-for-propose cattle grids, not get rid of them all together.Not only should road repairs be made to last but at the very least the roads department should clean up after itself and remove old damaged materials such as this left behind.If a private company or an inidual member of the public left a large amount of scrap metal at the side of the road they would be in trouble.I have contacted our roads management through member services and asked them to recty this matter as soon as possible.I am a GP in one of Argyll#s rural practices. Last week I was having a busy morning so was a little later than usual getting back to my car, which I had left charging at an electric charge point.That evening I was surprised to see that I#d been charged £ over and above the normal charging rate per KwH.I checked through the Argyll and Bute website and discovered that there is now an overstay charge – hence the surcharge.I had received an email back in April saying that Argyll and Bute Council would now be charging users at its charge points – the cost being p per KwH. Fair enough.However, there was no mention of a penalty for overstaying. Nor is there any notice at the charge points themselves, save a tiny notice stating #charges apply#.Those seeking to charge in Argyll and Bute are additionally confused by the lack of clarity over what type of charge point is being used: is it a  Kw, Kw or a  Kw. There is no notice on the chargers. This is important because the overstay timings y according to the dfering units.When I buy petrol at a filling station, I clearly know what the charges are when I buy a ticket at a parking meter, I buy a ticket and know exactly how long I am able to park there.But it seems that for electric vehicles you have to search the internet to find out the rules – and in my village there is no local WiFi and I cannot get G on my phone.As a responsible democrat I thought, when this election was called, that I would write to the candidates to ask them a few questions before deciding how to vote.We had no hustings this time, even in Campbeltown, and our MSP has not visited the town for ages. So election time seems to be the only opportunity to enter into dialogue with those who want to represent us.Last year I published a book about the uncertain future for the rule of law in Scotland. The irreducible basis of a rule-of-law society is reciprocity between those who make the laws and those who have to obey them. Without dialogue, that is impossible.Only two parties sent me a leaflet with enough time to allow an exchange of emails: first the SNP and then the LibDems.I started by asking the SNP candidate, Jenni Minto, for a CV. That was initially refused, then a redacted one sent. Next, I asked about the Hate Crime Act. I got a long answer ending with a quotation from the English philosopher, Karl Popper: #In order to maintain a tolerant society, the society must be intolerant to intolerance.#I wrote back quoting Bertrand Russell, who said that enforced morality is not morality at all it is pure obedience. Likewise, enforced tolerance is not tolerance, just obedience. I asked what she thought of the criminalisation of dinner-time conversations and other aspects of the Act. It was at that point that the dialogue broke down.I changed the subject to independence. This time I did get a reply, but it was evasive.For example, I had asked what the most important features of the UK were that made her want Scotland to leave it. Ms Minto replied that an independent country would get the government it votes for. That implied thatScotland and England voted for the same party, there would be no need for independence. So, by extension, whatArgyll wanted a dferent government from that in Holyrood  Should it declare independence from Scotland, as Orkney and Shetland have said they willthe UK breaks up  I wrote for clarication, but Ms Minto did not reply.I also wrote to Alan Reid of the LibDems. He sent a CV, but when I replied to that with questions about LibDem policy, I heard nothing more.That, in Scotland, appears to be the limit of dialogue between the rulers and the ruled. Perhaps that explains something about the parliament itself.With Sun Awareness Week taking place this week, Cats Protection would like to advise cat owners to be aware of the risks posed to their cat by the sun.Pale-coloured cats, or those with unpigmented white noses or ears, are particularly at risk from the sun#s rays which can cause sunburn and skin cancer.Those affected can suffer long-term damage including, in severe cases, having to have their ear tips removed to prevent the cancer from spreading.Following a few simple tips owners can help protect their cat from the harmful effects of the sun.These include keeping them indoors on sunny days between am and pm, asking your vet for advice about suitable sunscreen and ensuring you provide plenty of shade to enable your cat to shelter from the sun#s rays.

Yet, at the same time, we are becoming increasingly suspicious that the label on freedom has been switched.For some people appear to be devaluing freedom. They seem to think it means no constraints on their behaviour. They have the right to do whatever they want, evenit causes damage to themselves, to others and to the environment.Jesus makes it clear that freedom is something quite dferent. It is being set free from the tyrannical oppression of our own self-centredness – what the Bible calls sin – empowering us to be free to love God by willingly obeying his Word and to love others by humbly looking out for their best interests.Not only did Jesus tell us in his teaching and show us by his example what label freedom should have, but by his real death on the cross, his physical and historical resurrection and the gt of his Spirit, he made it possible for us to experience it.We must not be conned by the switch that has been made to freedom#s label.Instead, let us restore its label back to its correct, Jesus-defined and le-changing setting, and through faith in Jesus alone, value and enjoy the freedom he secured by his death.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.I would like to thank everybody who voted for me in the Scottish election and the many people who helped my campaign.I congratulate Jenni Minto on her election and wish her well in her job of representing the people of Argyll and Bute at Holyrood.The following is an open letter from John Gurr, chairperson of the Rest and Be Thankful Campaign group, to Transport Scotland#s chief executive, Roy Brannen, and director of roads, Hugh Gillies, in response to a follow-up email following a meeting held with officials from the transport agency last month. Dear Roy and Hugh,I am writing in response to an official Transport Scotlandemail to the Rest and Be ThankfulCampaign on April  , where you have sought to answer several questions posed by us at our meeting with your officials and in subsequent emails to you both. We are hugely disappointed by this response and its apparent contradictions.We asked for a permanent solution within the next three years. The email states: #We are not waiting for anything and are pushing on with work at pace#, yet your actions since the August landslide have only created delay.Creating  options for consultation in November , this, we believe, is a time-wasting exercise. Five further options for consultation in March. We strongly believe there are only three real options, with studies on these completed in your  report. Conducting a geological survey which will take eighteen months to complete, a process that could have started last August, assuming you had not conducted such surveys in .We have asked for temporary use of the forestry road, away from the threats posed by landsides. It also states: #We were clear without that information we are not certain the forestry track in its current form is safe for use.# Yet we would argue you already have a Transerv report produced in  by Balfour Beatty and Mouchal Services Ltd for TS which suggested the forestry road could be upgraded in  to  weeks. How did Transerv arrive at this conclusion without a study of the ground conditions being done in advance This situation should be considered a safety, economic and social emergency, cutting through the red tape of consultation and delay. It further declares: #We understand first-hand the delay that can be caused by procedural challenge…there needs to be a careful balancing of accelerating development and procedural risk in order to ensure that we do not end up in the courts.#While we understand the need for the right balance of speed and consultation, we think the safety risks, costs incurred by business and damage to the economy of Argyll, should create the conditions for emergency action, delivering what should be a simple road realignment. This is not HS, we are not asking to blight the countryside, or people#s homes, you do not have whole communities ready to challenge fixing the crisis at RABT.What we want cannot be worse than the damage already inflicted on the hillside without consultation. If you fixed the Rest, we will all be thankful.The following questions still have not been answered in TS#s official reply or in recent press statements:We are business people and understand the need for safe environments, effective procedures, timely management, and cost control, but what we have experienced over the past year does not give us confidence you will address the concerns we have.We are not looking for you to defend your approach, what matters to us is the action taken to bring timescales down and resolve the problem within the next parliament. We are simply asking you to rethink your approach, look at how your team can cut through this #business as usual# process and appoint someone who can find a way to realign two kilometres of the A safely within the next three years.By challenging your approach, we are hoping to see that after nearly a year of delay and ersion, there is a recognition of the cost impact to business, the signicant safety concerns, and that this will continue to blight Argyll as a place to live, work, and invest in until a permanent solution is delivered.We will be working with the relevant politicians post elections and will continue to campaign for a change in approach. We would be happy to discuss what can be done to overcome any constraints you have to deliver a solution quickly and resolve the crisis at the RABT.We stand at a once-in-a-generation crossroads.Earlier this week, a thought-provoking poem, ACCEPTABLE  by the Anonymous Mother # judged for needing a food bank to feed her child # started a nationwide debate about whether the world#s fth richest country should need food banks to feed children.This conversation needed to happen as our food bank crisis has become critical.Last year food banks in the Trussell Trust#s network handed out , emergency food parcels for children in the UK. This surely cannot be acceptable.However, fate has given us a rare opportunity, as history shows us that the best time to create a brighter future is after times of great darkness.The pandemic has been the most devastating event to hit our country since the Second World War, but it also brought out the very best of our nation.We recognised our real community heroes, we protected the vulnerable, we didn#t stand by when kids went hungry.But now, as we prepare to wake up from the pandemic nightmare, millions of British families still cannot afford food on their table.As the Anonymous Mother poetically says # it doesn#t need to be this way.In , Britain woke up to its new dawn at a similar crossroads # go back to the old broken way, or use this golden opportunity to make things better.That great generation chose hope, and created a better, fairer society for all # including founding the NHS.This pandemic has been our generation#s darkest hour. This is now our new dawn, our choice. Will we choose the old broken way, or use this golden opportunity to eradicate hunger in the UK I urge you to do just one thing today, and that is to seek out the poem that started all of this, and reflect.If, afterwards, you agree with me and the hundreds of thousands of other supporters of the Trussell Trust, that we can do better, join us as we collectively create a #hunger free future#.

We did a huge amount of work including introducing a one-way system, social distancing measures and putting down markers,” said theatre manager Paul Baines. “One of the biggest challenges was getting people in and out safely.“We have to ensure the measures are genuine and effective and they are visible. Visible reassurance is important for customer confidence.“It is a juggling act because you have to balance creating a too clinical atmosphere with offering a unique theatre experience.”The theatre has been awarded the VisitEngland We’re Good to Go industry standard mark, signying that it adheres to government and public health COVID- guidance, also approved by UK Theatre Seat Safety.‘People need care and pampering’ROSIE FRASER, OWNER,THAT ROSIE GLOW, EDINBURGHAlongside familiar COVID- safety measures, Rosie Fraser has introduced a new service called “Silent Treatment”.“We love a good chat but we also understand some people prefer not to,” said Rosie, whose beauty salon opened in .“Clients can see the service as soon as they look at the online booking menu and add it with whatever treatments they are having.“We still carry out a full consultation and then let them just relax.”Also in place are bespoke engraved screens between stations, extra time for cleaning, screening forms for track and trace, PPE and sanitising measures. Rosie emphasises that it is safety with style!Members of the seven-strong team are carrying out rapid COVID- tests at home thanks to the UK Government asymptomatic testing initiative.“We have exciting plans for this year in expanding. COVID- and lockdown has reaffirmed how much people need care and pampering to feel good.”‘Trade boost from vaccine confidence’JOHN LAVERY, OWNER,FISH CITY, BELFASTInvestment has helped Fish City in Belfast continue operating. The award-winning seafood restaurant extended its seating, installed outdoor heating and started a delivery service. Since reopening for outdoor dining, it has been doing a brisk trade bolstered by confidence in the vaccine programme. Reopening indoors is scheduled to start on May .“We created a dining room upstairs with a completely dferent feel,” said John, who owns the restaurant with his we Grainne. Safety processes include a digital thermometer mounted at the door which all staff and customers are required to pass before entering. Anyone recording a high temperature is refused admission.Hand sanitisers are also available. Kitchen and front of house staff are required to wear masks and wash their hands regularly. Tables and chairs are cleaned rigorously after every diner. The restaurant’s commitment to the safety is also seen in its recognition as COVID- Compliant by Tourism NI.‘We worked hard to train all the team’MEURIG JONES, LOCATION MANAGER,PORTMEIRION VILLAGE, PORTMEIRION“If I could do cartwheels, I would” is one retail chief’s response to welcoming the public back.“When we saw the first trickle of people coming back last month, it was lovely,” enthused village location manager MeurigJones. “Portmeirion needs people here.“It’s lovely but it isn’t what it should be without people appreciating it. We’re constantly improving and we’re learning as we go on.”App orders and one-way systems will ensure ongoing safety. Outside seating, pods and marquee are also available. Misting machines, meanwhile, will keep hotels“squeaky clean – safe for staff and guests”.Meurig added: “There’s hand sanitiser outside every shop and we ask people to wear masks indoors, but not outside.”

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.The Argyll coast is playing host to an eco-adventurer with a mission to bring the ocean’s plight to the world stage.Twenty-six-year-old Ben Taylor is currently kayaking and walking along the coastlines of Kintyre, Knapdale and Lorn as part of his round-Britain expedition.He is collecting litter as he travels and documenting it in a blog and photographs that he plans to take to the UN COP conference in Glasgow later this year.#I had been volunteering for conservation charities and reading into climate change, but had come to feel hopeless about the sheer scale of the problem,# Ben explains.#After thinking about it all for a few years I started looking in to what I could do and realised in December that one person can make a dference, particularly when combined with community efforts.#Ben describes his environmental mission as a personal journey that he embarked on after a period of depression.#The idea came to me one evening when I was standing in the kitchen chopping vegetables.#I was listening to a song # Albatross by Fleetwood Mac # and suddenly I broke down in tears.#From there the idea took hold and I got in touch with the Marine Conservation Society and the John Muir Trust and told them that I wanted to fundraise for them and highlight their work while doing this trip.#A website and an online fundraising page were next on Ben’s to-do list, followed soon after by a host of practicalities that he needed to work out.Ben says: #I’ll be on the go around Scotland until COP in November and then continuing on to England.#I can’t carry much food as I’ve already got a tent, stove, inflatable kayak and paddles. I was really pleased to find a company that does dehydrated vegan food in compostable bags, so I bought  meals and have mailed them in batches to post offices around the country so I can collect them as I travel.#As far as training for such an extraordinary expedition is concerned, Ben explained that he has participated in several endurance events, including multi-day running, in the past, but, now three weeks since he left his starting point of Glasgow he is enjoying this trip more than these previous competitions.#I’m loving this as it’s not all ‘Go, Go , Go’. I want to be able to sit back and take time and explore all the dferent parts of the coast. This trip has given me time to write, which is something I’ve wanted to do for a while.#Ben’s blog can be read on his website where he has also written in detail about the threat plastic litter poses to marine le and the environment in general.#I wasn’t brought up by the sea I’m from Manchester,# Ben adds. #I worked at a youth hostel in Ullapool for a couple of years and felt a connection there.#When I’m picking up rubbish on beaches I feel really up and down about it all.#I feel so sad about what I find, and also about the amount that’s below the ocean’s surface. But then I realise I need to do what I can.#On that note, Ben is keen to work together with locals who want to make a dference.He is helping out at a beach clean in Oban this Friday, May . Information on this and how to donate to the John Muir Trust or the Marine Conservation Society can be found on Ben’s www.ukcoastjourney website.

title: former-ross-high-pupil-ruari-paton-aiming-scottish-cup-glory
story: Ruari Paton will be hoping to line up for Stranraer todaywhen they make the long journey north to face Brora Rangers, who stunned Hearts in the previous round.The frontman attended the Tranent secondary school after signing for Hibernian as a teenager and making the move from Dublin.Many had expected Stranraer to be travelling to Tynecastle this weekend but Brora caused one of the biggest shocks in the competitionrsquos history when they won - last Tuesday.Paton was part of the Stranraer team taking on Brechin City at the same time and said that his reaction was much the same as football fans up and down the country when he heard the result.He said: ldquoI would not like to take anything away from Brora but you donrsquot really hear of a Championship team getting beaten by a Highland League or a Lowland League team ever.ldquoIt was a shock, it was a big shock, but fair play to them.ldquoWhat an achievement it is and it is an amazing challenge to overcome.ldquoYou cannot take anything away from them.Stranraer have enjoyed an impressive start to the campaign, with just one defeat since the beginning of November, as they look toto League One.Paton, who now lives in Bothwell, South Lanarkshire, has been at the heart of that form, scoring eight goals in all competitions, with strikes against Spartans and a last-minute penalty winner against Kelty Hearts in the previous round.He has also found the net for Gala Fairydean Rovers, while on loan from Hibs, and for East Kilbride in the competition last year.Now, attention has turned to the trip to Brora and Paton said: ldquoTherersquos nothing better in the world than scoring. Any forward player will tell you that. If you have a terrible game and score a goal or play fantastic and not score ndash you are judged on your goals as a forward.ldquoHopefully, I will get another goal but I need to make sure I am in the team. I would love another goal and I love the Scottish Cup. I loved it with East Kilbride and Gala Fairydean Rovers ndash it is great and you love those big moments in competitions.Paton moved from Dublin to East Lothian after signing for Hibs around his th birthday.He lived with Helen Leslie and her two sons, Darren and Jonathan, off Tranentrsquos Waterloo Road and attended Ross High School, where he studied physical education, English and sports leadership.The striker was quick to praise both the family and the school for helping him develop. He said: ldquoThey took me in asI was part of their family.ldquoThey were absolutely fantastic to me and made me feel so welcome.ldquoI went for dinner with them and they were brilliant.ldquoIn my first year, I spoke to Sean McPartlin, education and welfare officer, and he askedI wanted to do something. I agreed to it and they said I would train some days.ldquoIt is the best thing I ever did.That saw Paton ide his time between attending school and training at Hibernian Training Centre at East Mains on the outskirts of Ormiston.The -year-old spent two years at the secondary school and told Courier Sport how much he enjoyed the experience. He added: ldquoIt was brilliant ndash the best thing I ever did, honestly.ldquoI was not too keen going to school at that age with football andI had not then I would not have made many friends. The amount of people I met through school was unbelievable.Paul Reynolds, headteacher of the Tranent secondary school, said: ldquoNot only was Ruari a standout footballer, he was a true gentleman.ldquoHe was always extremely polite and his positive attitude was infectious. I have rarely met someone so filled with optimism.ldquoWith his lsquogo get lsquoemrsquo attitude, he settled into Ross High School very quickly and it was a pleasure to have him here. Irsquom delighted to hear that he is still playing and wish him all the very best.

title: musselburgh-churches-helping-food-donations-pandemic

To book a seat, please get in touch via info@musselburghbaptist.org or message us through our Facebook page , where we also livestream our .am service.The Rev Dr Leslie Milton, minister at St Andrewrsquos High Church, said: ldquoWe have had a particular focus on supporting East Lothian Foodbank throughout the pandemic and members were active in Resilient Musselburgh while it was operating.ldquoOur morning worship is at am in church and on Facebook. We hold an additional service on a Tuesday afternoon once a month for those who are unable to come out in the morning.ldquoWe have a weekly coffee morning and occasional discussion groups on Zoom. title: get-paid-drink-beer-thanks-musselburgh-universitys-study
story: Itrsquos looking for  people to take part in a consumer taste trial where they will sample the beer.Run by the universityrsquos Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation, the team is recruiting  people who are already stout drinkers ndash those who enjoy the occasional pint of Guinness, Belhaven Black or Murphyrsquos ndash as well as  who have not drunk stout before but are keen to try it.Recruitment for tasters starts now, with the trial to begin later this month.Each participant who completes tastings and provides the necessary feedback will be rewarded with a pound John Lewis or Amazon voucher as a thank you for taking part.Participants, ideally from Edinburgh and the Lothians, will be asked to pick up samples from the university and will be given two sample stout recipes to taste at home. They will need to complete an online questionnaire to provide feedback and highlight their preferred sample. Access to the internet is essential and the feedback process is believed to take about - minutes to complete.Catriona Liddle, who heads up the Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation, is running the trial.She said: ldquoOur consumer tasting  are extremely popular with foodies and people from the local community who enjoy sampling and talking about food and drink. Itrsquos open to people who are already part of our existing consumer , but itrsquos also an opportunity for new people who might like to get involved in further food and drink tasting .ldquoWe normally have multiple sessions running on campus each week across all food types. The only consideration is that sadly we cannot accept any applications from those with food allergies or food restrictions.ldquoThe samples on this trial will be blind tested, so participants wonrsquot know which type of stout they are tasting, and we will be using the results to help create Scotlandrsquos favourite stout.Email the food team at consumer@qmu.ac.uk to apply.Participants must be aged  and over.

title: scotland-home-year-inside-katie-spiers-home
story: ldquoI didnrsquot really have TV in my mind, says Spiers, , ldquoit wasnrsquot something I thought I would ever do. Irsquove always been happy with my online job and content creation, but when I went for a meeting with the team, I just loved them ndash they were so passionate about the show, and I just thought lsquookay, letrsquos try it out!rsquoThe popular home show continues to attract a strong following in its third series,Spiers believes demand will be at an all-time high. ldquoI think itrsquos a really great programme to go on after so long in lockdown, she highlights.ldquoWhen everyonersquos been looking at the same four walls for the last year, lots of people have big plans for what theyrsquore going to do with their homes, and for when they can have tradesmen back into the house, so I think watching an interiors show is going to be inspiring for people hellip a welcome bit of voyeurism.Despite the fluctuating restrictions of the pandemic last year, the crew, alongside Spiersrsquos fellow judges interior designer Anna Campbell-Jones and architect Michael Angus, were able to film series three last September.ldquoI would not recommend filming during a pandemic, laughs Spiers. ldquoWe would do Covid tests every couple of days, get temperature checks twice a day ndash we constantly had thermometers hanging out of our mouths.ldquoWe were really lucky we could get out to film, and it was great to see more of Scotland.Originally from New Zealand, Spiers considers herself an honorary Scot since moving here as a child. The content creator has a weighty , followers on Instagram, many of whom were gained over the last year alone. ldquoMy following grew massively during the pandemic, she explains, ldquowhereas it hadnrsquot grown that much in the last couple of years.One of the main reasons for this influx is Spiersrsquos dreamy, aesthetically pleasing interiors.ldquoI would think my niche, or my USP, is probably that I live quite a simple le ndash I view my content as being attainable but slightly aspirational.ldquoMy husband and I live in a three-bedroom tenement flat in the southside of Glasgow ndash itrsquos far from a mansion, but it has period detailing and wersquove done a lot of work to make it our own and inject our personality into it. Itrsquos also a style that is easy to replicate.ldquoIrsquom quite inspired by Southern Calornian style ndash lots of wood and greenery, earthy tones, and textures. I bring a lot of that into my home, I love rattan and a bit of s style. I think Irsquove created quite a colourful home that brings me a lot of joy.So, after being able to add TV presenter to her ever-growing CV, whatrsquos next for Spiers  ldquoWriting is my passion, she emphasises. ldquoI would love to write a book one day, a collection of essays, I think ndash thatrsquos something Irsquove always been leading up to. Although everybody always wants me to do an interiors book!Kate shares her top tips to freshen up your home for springThere is no better time to refresh your home than the start of a new season, and the arrival of spring definitely brings with it a chance to declutter and revive your space. So, throw open your windows, stock up on blossom-scented cleaning supplies and follow my steps for freshening up your home for spring hellipDeep clean and declutter:Spring is the perfect time to assess your home and see what you can donate or throw out. Irsquove made multiple trips to the recycling centre lately and it really has made a dference to my home ndash I know Irsquoll never be a minimalist, but it feels calming to have a little less clutter at least.Set aside an hour or so once a week to clear out your wardrobe, kitchencabinets and hallway cupboards.Reorganise sideboards and shelves, and get rid of anything you havenrsquot used or worn in a while ndash be ruthless! Then give everything a once-over as you go ndash spring cleaning is good for the soul.Have a room refresh: Changing the layout of a room and giving your home a bit of a rejig does wonders for making the space feel like new. Once or twice a year Irsquoll consider how I can switch up my spaces. Irsquoll move furniture, swap out soft furnishings, relocate the sofa to another position or change our spare room completely. Irsquoll even rework the gallery walls and artwork around my home. Itrsquos like redecorating but without spending a penny.Bring the outdoors: in Stock up on tulips, daffodils and peonies, and place bouquets around your home ndash on mantelpieces, sideboards, kitchen worktops and coffee tables. Irsquom a big fan ofgreenery in the home too ndash plants like Pothos, Monstera deliciosa and ZZ plants are so easy to take care of and really breathe a bit of le into a room. Irsquom all about the indoor jungle, so go wild with blooms and plants and your home will feel bright and breezy in no time.Consider a lick of paint: With so many fun paint brands launching lately , itrsquos easier than ever to add colour to your le. Opt for a fresh eucalyptus green to revive a bathroom, or pick a played-down pink for warmth. Go wild with it ndash paint a feature wall in your living room or section off a room with a dado rail and paint the lower section a bright shade. Bold colours never go out of style.www.katelavie

title: new-gps-nurses-call-handlers-join-riverside-medical-practice-musselburgh
story: Two new GPs, two nurse practitioners and two new call handlers have taken up jobs at the surgery since the start of the year, with a further GP due to arrive in the summer and two GPs due tofrom maternity leave.Recruitment for one more GP is ongoing, with a fresh recruitment push due to launch shortly to coincide with new GPs entering the workplace as their training comes to an end.Dr Richard Kitto, a long-standing doctor at the practice, has been made a GP partner.The Courier has previously reported that the practice has come under fire from frustrated patients who have complained about dficulties contacting it to secure appointments.Commenting on the recruitment drive, Dr Richard Fairclough, GP partner, said: ldquoWe must stress to all of our patients and stakeholders in the local community that this remains an exceptionally busy time for general practices all over the country. Our successful recruitment is good news but wersquore now ndash with the exception of one GP, a nurse practitioner and the further call handlers ndash at the limit of the number of people we can employ at the practice yet we estimate that demand for appointments will still outweigh our capacity to provide them.He explained: ldquoWe must therefore continue to stress the urgent need for the full implementation of the  GMS Contract, which lays out the ious types of care due to be removed from the remit of general practice, in order to allow GPs to provide the expert medical care to the local community that we so desperately want to be able to do.He added: ldquoThis is widely recognised to be a challenging time to recruit GPs, with more GPs leaving the Scottish workforce each year than new GPs entering it.ldquoSo given this, wersquore especially delighted to welcome our two new GPs to the practice. Dr Maeve Chestnutt joined us from the Forth Valley Practice in March after relocating to East Lothian and Dr Michael Slowey has joined us last week from a practice in Sussex after locuming with us for a short time.He continued: ldquoWersquod also like to extend warm congratulations to Dr Kitto, who joins myself, Dr Cameron and Dr Stenke as a GP partner.Dr Fairclough said: ldquoTheirs arenrsquot the only new faces at the practice this year. Senior nurse practitioner Chris Gent has joined us as clinical manager from NHS , bringing his considerable clinical and operational experience to Riverside, along with nurse practitioner Sarah Miller.ldquoFinally, wersquore so pleased to welcome a further two new call handlers to our reception team, with more to follow shortly. Being a GP receptionist is such a challenging role, requiring a deep knowledge of how the surgery works, as well as calmness under pressure, and outstanding customer service skills. We know our two new recruits are going to make a great contribution to our now -strong reception team.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-may-10-14-1996-1971-1921
story: A BID to ban booze in a North Berwick park was being proposed, reported the East Lothian Courier on May , .An alcohol exclusion zone could be created in North Berwick as part of a joint police and community initiative to curb underage drinking in town.Plans are underway to ban alcohol from the Lodge Grounds public park ndash a popular haunt for teeny tipplers.A similar scheme is already operating in several streets in Prestonpans ndash the first town in the district to introduce no-go areas for public drinking ndash and police in North Berwick are keen to follow suit.They hope to get the backing of nearby residents and the local community council before taking the idea to East Lothian Licensing Board for formal approval.The matter was discussed at the monthly meeting of North Berwick Community Council on Tuesday.Sergeant Alistair McIntyre warned that banning the drinking of alcohol in the park could push the underage tipplers to other areas of the town, possibly the harbour.FIVE generations of the same family were in attendance at a baptism in Dunbar, told The Haddingtonshire Courier on May , .When baby Kathleen Lorimer was baptised in Dunbar Parish Church, her father, grandfather, great-grandfather and great-great-grandfather were there to watch the ceremony.The occasion marked the first time the five generations had gathered together.Baby Kathleen Vanessa is the daughter of Mr Tom Lorimerand his we, Avril.Her grandfather, Mr John Lorimer, gardener, and his we Chris, were there, as were her great-grandfather, Mr Tom Lorimer, a foreman with North Berwick Town Council, and his we Jean.The eldest member of the party was -year-old Mr John Lorimer.TWO men appeared in court after stealing planks of wood from a mine, as reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on May , .On Friday, at Haddington Sherf Court, Peter Devannah, labourer and John Devannah, miner, both from Tranent, pleaded guilty to having on Saturday rd April, stolen four planks of wood from the pithead of Bankton colliery.The Fiscal said that the accused and another man were seen carrying planks up the railway line from the pit.When the police followed them, they made off.The accused were overtaken, but the third man escaped.They were taken back to the pit and admitted having stolen the wood.They were each fined s.

title: tims-book-road-legends-chapter-14-great-wood-caledon
story: FINN walked by the side of Lochan nam Arm, peering into the water in his search for Robert the Brucersquos sword. Then, something caught his eye.He ran to Izzy: ldquoAunty, aunty, look what I found!He was holding a scarf.ldquoIt was hanging on a tree over there, he said.It was a short neck scarf, with Celtic interlacing design it looked new and unworn, possibly even handmade.ldquoI really love it aunty, can I keep it Izzy pursed her lips in thought.ldquoI dunno, Finn, someone may have dropped it and another person found it and placed it on the tree to keep it safe. Perhaps one of those walkers earlier. Maybe they will come back and look for it Finn wasnrsquot even half listening. He put the scarf on and rushed to the loch side to look at his reflection.ldquoIt would be safer round my neck surely  he called out.As he arranged the scarf, a folded piece of paper fell to the ground and landed by Finnrsquos feet. He picked it up, unfolded it and ran to Izzy, very excited.ldquoLook, the scarf is for me! he exclaimed.A worried look came over Izzyrsquos face as Finn handed her the piece of paper. There were beautully drawn Celtic designs, with images of what looked like faeries hiding in a wood.There was also a sleeping dragon curled round a heart shape in which there was handwriting: ldquoIf you have found me, and you like me, then Irsquom yours. Keep me safe, until itrsquos time to give me away.Izzy looked at Finn, nodded and smiled. ldquoSo it seems.ldquoI will never give this away! he insisted. He looked around at the trees and ed the gaze to his aunt.ldquoMaybe yoursquore right, aunty, maybe fairies do exist after all, at least here we are in the Highlands after all.He thought for a moment. ldquoOr maybe itrsquos just someone kind who likes to give presents.Finn headed back to the tree where hersquod found the scarf. He arranged twigs and broken bits of heather on the ground next to the tree and beckoned his aunt to come see.She looked down at what hersquod done. She didnrsquot immediately see it, but then realised that the twigs and heather formed letters.He carefully read it: ldquoThank you.ldquoThatrsquos lovely Finn, whoever left the scarf will see this and be very happy, Irsquom sure of it.Izzy looked up to the sky. The predicted rain was going to hold off.ldquoFinn, she said hesitantly, ldquowould you be up for a bit of an adventure ldquoYou mean a walk, donrsquot you ldquoKind of, aye, but this is to a place I have never been before, although Irsquove often seen it from a distance.ldquoHow far  asked Finn.Izzy pointed: ldquoJust there, where those old trees are. Itrsquos a small remnant of the old Caledonian forest, Irsquove often wanted to visit it but have never had the opportunity. Itrsquos not so far, but it might be a bit dficult to reach, Irsquove never explored it before.Finn wasnrsquot sure.Izzy helped him decide: ldquoIt might have a connection to the original Merlin.That sold it to him.ldquoWell, I have my boots, he smiled, ldquocan I lead the way So they set off in the direction of Coille Coire Chuic, a small remnant of the ancient Caledonian forest. Izzy let Finn decide on the route and as they neared the wood they arrived at the River Cononish. There was no obvious and safe way to cross, but Izzy was sure there was a small bridge downriver.The route got increasingly boggy and Izzy suspected Finn may want to give up, but instead he took the role of leader seriously and carefully planned each step, identying dryer patches and helping his aunt. They made slow progress, but with much hilarity as they balanced on small tufts of dry land surrounded by bog myrtle.Finn paused and listened. The noise of a waterfall could be heard ahead and he aimed for it. Izzy lagged behind to take in the beauty of the heather, which carpeted the ground with a blaze of purple and pink. The old Scots pines on the other side of the river looked magnicent, framed by the mountains beyond.She caught up with Finn, who was sitting on a rock watching the waterfall. It cascaded into a hidden pool, where the water twirled and bubbled asin a giant cauldron. Scots pine trees stood guard on the edge of it, one growing precariously from the overhanging rocks, its trunk curving upwards so its higher branches reached the sunlight. A gnarled rowan with vivid berries grew from the rocks on the other side, while on the opposite bank birch trees clung onto the steep side of the river, bent over like weeping willows.Finn wanted to sit awhile and so Izzy took it as an opportunity to make a brew for them both. He was beginning to understand that using her small camping stove was an important ritual for his aunt: the hissing sound, the waiting, the trail of steam, the anticipation it made a warm feeling, turned a wild place into home.They sipped tea together and shared well-earned snacks. Finn waited, expecting his aunt to tell a story. Finally, she did.ldquoSee that giant boulder over there, Finn, it was dropped by the giants who sculpted this land many years ago.ldquoLike with Samsonrsquos stone we saw Izzy nodded.Finn raised a cynical eyebrow and half a smile.ldquoHuge giants, Finn, a race called the Fomorians. The legend says they emerged from the sea long ago ndash grotesque troll-like creatures, incredibly powerful and cruel. Two of them made Rannoch Moor their home and they terrorised the people for miles around, destroying homes and taking livestock.ldquoNobody knew what to do, even the bravest and best warriors were defeated by them, ripped apart without mercy. Then a young lad about your age had his home destroyed by one of the giants, and in his grief he decided to rid the land of them.ldquoBut how could he do thateven the best warriors couldnrsquot Izzy gave him a wry smile, which he knew meant that was a good question and that she was just about to answer it.ldquoThe lad was wise. He had noticed how the two giants argued with each other about who was the stronger.ldquoSo he got them to fight each other ldquoKind of, he persuaded them to have a competition to see who could throw a stone furthest. They began hurling bigger and bigger stones, then they tore chunks of rock off the mountain sides. Soon the land was littered with boulders, and after three days the two giants were utterly exhausted.ldquoThen the young lad told one of the giants he had won, for he knew this would cause a fight. And so it did.ldquoThe giants fought each other with fury, using up what energy they had left. Finally, one gave the other a fatal blow, but it was the last thing he did, as he collapsed with total exhaustion.ldquoThey had killed each other ldquoYes, smiled Izzy, filling her cup with more tea and raising it. ldquoThatrsquos why the land around here is littered with all these huge stones.ldquoI know giants are mythological, aunty.Izzy sipped some tea.ldquoDepends what kind of giants you mean.Finn looked at the boulder.ldquoThe next tale is the gt of the sun, continued Izzy.ldquoAfter the death of the giants the land was bathed in sunshine, bringing new le.It became a green world, grass and plants grew, then trees arrived. The ancestors of this tree were first to arrive, she pointed to the nearby silver birch.ldquoOthers followed: the rowan, the aspen, alder and even oak. But it was these trees which made the forest canopy: Scots pines, also called Caledonian pines, an old name given to them by the Romans. Arenrsquot they a beautul tree Finn peered at the Scots pines around them.ldquoCreatures filled the forest with their songs, their roars, their grunting and howling the birds, bears, wolves, elk, deer and boar. Seven thousand years ago, where we sit we would have been amidst the Caledonian forest in its prime. Those trees over there are the descendants of that forest. If you sit with them and feel their presence, they will tell you their stories.Finn chuckled at his aunt, then explained why. ldquoYou are like Yoda! He defensively held up his hands to explain: ldquoNot the way you look, I mean the way you speak about things.Finn was a Star Wars fan. He had all three films on video at home and knew much of the dialogue by heart. He spoke to Izzy, mimicking Yodarsquos voice: ldquoSearch the force, le creates it, makes it grow, its energy surrounds us and binds us, luminous beings are we. Finn gently pinched Izzy on the shoulder, saying: ldquoNot this crude matter. You must feel the force around you, the tree, the rock, everywhere.Izzy laughed out loud, feeling rather flattered to be compared to one of Finnrsquos screen heroes. She thanked him for the compliment.Finn looked over at the old Scots pines on the other side of the river. He knew his aunt wanted to reach them and they were tantalisingly close, yet the river was too dangerous to cross.ldquoLetrsquos find a way to get there, he ventured.They packed up and followed the river, eventually finding a place to cross. They sat amidst the flowering heather under the canopy of old trees, near a clearing so a light breeze kept the midges at bay. As promised, Izzy spun legends of Merlin, but also other tales connected to the ancient forest: of Lailoken, the Picts and St Columba, and the sad tale of the last wolf. Finn added tales of his own, about Jedi Knights and what he could remember of the story of Tam Linn. The forest was both their theatre and audience. But there was a sense of melancholy in this wood, for something was missing: it was bereft of young trees. The old pines were missing their children.The walk back was much quicker and they arrived back at the car tired, but with a sense of achievement. It felt asthey had been in a dferent world.ldquoCan we camp tonight aunty  asked Finn. ldquoAnd have a campfire like the first night ldquoLetrsquos see how the weather holds and how we feel later, she replied, keeping options open.Food was now a priority and Izzy was keen to get away from the busyness of Tyndrum. Soon they were on their way, heading for Loch Tulla, where she planned to make their tea. She knew Ewen would already be at the Bridge of Orchy. What she didnrsquot know was his mum was with him, Finnrsquos grandmother, whom Finn had loved so much.She was waiting with her son in his car, literally trembling with emotion, desperate to see her beloved grandson, whom she hadnrsquot seen for more than four and a half years.Here are the links to chapters one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, , ,  and .

title: section-a1-closed-overnight-later-month-work-overhead-lines
story: Roadworks on the A, between the Thistly Cross and Abbotsview junctions, mean that the road will be closed from pm on May  until am the following day.A spokesman for Bear Scotland confirmed that work was being carried out by Keltbray on behalf of ScottishPower.He said that Keltbray had produced a statement, which reads: ldquoKeltbray, on behalf of ScottishPower, are carrying out essential work on a section of overhead lines between May  at pm to May  at am which will result in the closure of a section of the A.ldquoThis will include work on the high voltage and low voltage networks, changing electricity poles and overhead power cables.ldquoWe are replacing and refurbishing equipment which is coming to the end of its serviceable le, which is essential works to make sure we maintain a good quality of supply for our customers.ldquoA ersion route will be in place.ldquoAccess for emergency vehicles will be maintained at all times.

title: bbcs-money-nothing-salvages-items-kinwegar-recycling-centre-wallyford
story: Salvage superhero Sarah Moore was at the East Lothian Council-run site at Kinwegar recently to pick up unwanted goods, give them a new lease of le and turn them into cash for their original owners.The presenter spoke to three East Lothian men ndash two from Musselburgh and one from Elphinstone ndash who arrived at the skips to dispose of the three items.They were delighted to hand them over to her and appear on the programme, which was aired on BBC last month.Michael Clague, the owner of the four-man tent, from Musselburgh, said it was ldquopast its use-by date.He said: ldquoIrsquom just glad the tent is going to be recycled as it was sitting in our garage for some time.Sarah took it to award-winning bag maker Neil Wragg, who turned the old tent into  tote bags, which were sold to people all over the country via social media.Sarah visited the Honest Toun to hand over pound to Michael, who said he would use the cash for a homecoming for his son, who was at sea, and donate some to the Tranent-based Walk with Scott Foundation to help with its charity work.Another Musselburgh man, Alan, was getting ready to throw away a glass-topped coffee table. He and his partner felt it might not now be safe with grandchildren around the house.Sarah took the ldquoretro restoration project to East London-based, award-winning wallpaper, textile and surface designer Daniel Heath, who transformed the table with a custom screenprint design, and spray etch pattern on new toughened glass.Sarah again visited the original owner at his home in Musselburgh to hand over pound profit after the tablersquos sale to a furniture and interior shop in Northumberland. Alan said he planned to treat his grandchildren to a day out with the money he received.An old miniature greenhouse, brought to the centre by George, from Elphinstone, and believed to be an lsquoapprenticersquo piece dating from the s, was rescued to be worked on by Sarah herself at her West Sussex base.ldquoItrsquos a shame to put it in the skip but Irsquom trying to clear out, George said.Sarah went on to turn it into ldquoa vintage greenhouse with a bit of quirkiness by adding new panes of clear and coloured perspex to create a stained glass effect. She filled the fully al greenhouse with plants, selling it to a private buyer via social media.Back at his home in Elphinstone, a delighted George received pound from the sale, which he planned to give to his two sons.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe were very pleased that the programme chose to visit our recycling centre, which provides a valuable service to local residents.The programme can be viewed at bbc programmes mvl

title: historic-dunbar-methodist-church-saved-public-use
story: Dunbar Methodist Church ndash the oldest existing Methodist church in Scotland ndash dates back to .However, in , the congregations of Dunbar Methodist Church and nearby St Annersquos Scottish Episcopal Church merged and began meeting at the latter.The Victoria Street building was later sold, with developer Monkscroft Properties Limited keen to ensure that ldquothe building remained in use as a public space and as an asset for the community of Dunbar.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department has given the go-ahead to change the building into a venue for weddings, s and community use.Ewan McIntyre, who is behind the scheme, was delighted to see progress being made.He said: ldquoThe best reason to buy the building was to make sure it did not get turned into housing. It is part of the fabric of Dunbar.Minimal changes are planned for the building, with replacement steps outside.The main church space has capacity for about  people for worship, with the developers looking to host ldquosmall and intimate weddings, with a reduced capacity of up to  people seated for lunch or dinner and up to  people in total for ceremonies and celebrations.Stained glass windows have been repaired, while other decoration has been completed inside the building.Members of the public will get the chance to look around the venue on May  and  at an open door event.However, the proposals did not win favour with everyone in the town.The planning department received three letters objecting to the plans, with concerns that there would be loud music played at the venue, disturbance with people congregating before, during and after events, and worries about where people attending events would park their cars.During the planning process, the applicants highlighted ldquorelationships with neighbours are crucial to the success of the venue and the utmost care will be given to managing guests and noise.Dunbarrsquos community council was among those who backed the proposals when they were first lodged with the local authority in summer last year.Pippa Swan, community council chairwoman, was pleased the scheme was progressing.She highlighted that the building was not listed and it could have been demolished or transformed to make way for housing.She was pleased the building would remain in community use.Mrs Swan said: ldquoWe are absolutely thrilled.ldquoI know that the Methodist church building, when it was a place of worship and dwindling congregation, was an uphill struggle to keep the building in good repair.ldquoIt is fantastic that it has got a new owner and wonderful it is being kept as a place of public assembly.

title: east-lothians-jamie-ramsay-cycling-across-uk-80-days-drum-support-olympics
story: Jamie Ramsay had planned to travel to the international showcase last year, cycling and sailing the whole way from London to Tokyo.But the coronavirus pandemic saw the event pushed back  months, with Jamie, from Whittingehame, now going on a journey with a dference.It will see him complete  days of socially distanced cycling around the UK through June and July.The -year-old, sponsored by Whole Earth , said: ldquoIrsquom disappointed not to be able to go the whole way to Japan but am really looking forward to meeting fellow Team GB supporters in Scotland and around Britain.ldquoWersquore all in this pandemic together and need a bit of fun. I hope my passion and determination to do this challenge will get people in Scotland behind our Team GB heroes and show the benefits of exercise and nutrition on positive mental attitude and wellbeing.The journey will take Jamie ndash who has previously cycled from Sao Paulo in Brazil to Boliviarsquos La Paz, and run from Vancouver in Canada to Argentinarsquos capital city Buenos Aires ndash around Britain.The former Belhaven Hill, Stenton Primary and Loretto School pupil will pass through towns and cities twinned with or named after places along his original route, including Moscow in East Ayrshire and Holland in Hampshire.Instead of ending up in Tokyo, he will be crossing the finishing line in lsquoStokeyorsquo, also known as Stoke-on-Trent.Visiting Team GB athletesrsquo families, schools and fans en route, Jamie will record their cheers and waves on doorsteps, creating the biggest virtual Mexican wave to spur on Team GB hopefuls.His gruelling challenge will also see him climb Ben Nevis, cycle Hadrianrsquos Wall, and swim the Blue Lagoon in Abereiddy in south-west Wales.Last Tuesday, two-time Olympic rowing champion Helen Glover fired the starting gun from Londonrsquos  Queen Elizabeth Park to signal the start of Jamiersquos journey.Helen, who is aiming for a hat-trick of Olympic gold medals when the Games get under way in July, said: ldquoOur fans mean everything to us but wersquore now facing a Games this summer with no British spectators in Tokyo.ldquoJamiersquos epic journey to help get fans behind us is awe-inspiring. We have so much respect for his perseverance and hope hersquoll spur us on to bring gold home for our fans this summer.Follow Jamiersquos progress at wholeearthfoods teamgb wholewayjourney

title: new-use-approved-former-mens-club-haddington
story: East Lothian Property has been given approval to make the changes in the former Haddington Recreation Club, which closed its doors more than  years ago.The office would be created on the ground floor of the Sidegate building, with a two-bedroom flat created on both the first and second floors.The developer said: ldquoWe are keen to preserve this historic building forming an important part of the Haddington townscape."Our proposals will provide a viable way to maintain and preserve this historic property.No members of the public registered an objection to the plans.The planning officerrsquos report reads: ldquoThe proposed change of use to offices and two flats would not result in signicant harm to the amenity of the area, including the amenity of neighbouring properties."Future occupants of the proposed flats would benefit from privacy and amenity.

title: fixed-penalty-tickets-given-drivers-breaching-rules-outside-haddington-schools
story: Restrictions at drop-off and pick-up times during the school term are in place on the townrsquos Neilson Park Road.Police officers monitored the issue on the morning of April  after complaints about drivers ignoring restrictions.A spokesperson for Police Scotland said: ldquoThe prohibition order was put in place to reduce the amount of vehicular traffic on certain roads, making it safer for children and families travelling to and from school."Two fixed penalty tickets were issued to drivers."Officers will continue to monitor this and take enforcement action when required.

title: north-berwicks-catriona-matthew-unveils-solheim-cup-sculpture-gleneagles
story: Europe edged out the United States frac - frac to win the competition at Gleneagles for the first time since .Now, a commemorative sculpture, created by Scottish artist Jephson Robb, has been unveiled in front of the captain and key representatives from Gleneagles, Event Scotland and PING Europe.Catriona, who won the Solheim Cup three times as a player, unveiled lsquoMatchrsquo last month.She said: ldquoTeam Europersquos victory on Scottish soil will always remain one of the greatest achievements of my career.ldquoIrsquom sure this wonderful sculpture will also remind the many thousands who visit Gleneagles each year of a truly exceptional Solheim Cup I will certainly never forget.Catriona, of North Berwick, is due to lead Team Europe again later this year as they look to retain the trophy at the Inverness Club in Ohio, with the tournament teeing off on August .Jephson ndash one of only a few Scottish artists to have work in the permanent collection of the prestigious Museum of Modern Art, New York ndash was commissioned to create a permanent sculpture as a lasting reminder of the event.More than , spectators visited the -acre Perthshire estate, a record attendance for a womenrsquos UK golf tournament.At . metres tall, referencing the average height of the competitors, the stainless-steel mirror polished sculpture sits atop a Scottish Whinstone circular plinth which is inscribed with the names of players, captains and assistants, and the final score.

title: modern-day-makeover-historic-ormiston-footpath
story: The path, known locally as Clarty Loan, links Park Road and Limeylands Road.It was once used by coal miners on their way to and from work at the four mines surrounding the village.It is now used by local residents as a shortcut to the local shops, park and primary school, and is also seen as a safe route since it is not suitable for vehicles.With new homes being built in and around Ormiston, Ormiston West Tenants and Residents Association suggested that upgrading the path would be of great benefit to the local community and area.Walker Homes, which is building properties in the west of the village, agreed to fund the reinstatement of the path and pay East Lothian Council to do so.The improvement works consist of new lighting along the walkway.The issue of lighting along Clarty Loan was raised with the local housing partnership at East Lothian Council, which agreed to fund light installation.Mark Ormiston, Ormiston West Tenants and Residents Association chairman, said: ldquoNow all the agreed work has been done and the path is looking fantastic.Peter Matthews, Walker Group managing director, said: ldquoWersquove worked hard to deliver a well-designed place to be enjoyed by families who live in the Long Meadow development and the wider village.ldquoAs part of our agreement with the council, we provided funds to ensure the path which runs along the side of the development was upgraded.ldquoAs a responsible developer, as well as delivering high-quality developments for our customers, wersquore committed to providing opportunities to enhance the local area and contribute investment to benefit surrounding communities.

title: traditional-tents-replaced-wooden-cabins-holiday-campsite
story: Scripture Union Scotland has been running camping holidays at Scoughall Farm, east of North Berwick, since the early s.Now, changes to the campsite will see five wooden cabins, as well as a pod, put in place of the tents.The charity, which uses the site from March through to October, runs ldquomulti-activity, resident events for young people.It said: ldquoThis change will enable us to meet the changing expectations of young people without departing from the historical style of the campsite.ldquoThe new buildings will be located in the same area as the tents were pitched and will allow the site to be used to its full potential throughout the season.ldquoThere is no plan to increase the capacity of the site or theof the season.ldquoThe buildings will be supplied with electricity by linking to the on-site supply or from small inidual solar units attached to each building ndash there will be no other utilities supplied.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department approved the proposals last week, with no members of the public objecting to the scheme.The local authority imposed two conditions: that the accommodation can be used only from March to October, and only by Scripture Union Scotland or an organisation on its behalf.

title: former-animal-mart-east-linton-given-go-ahead-host-parties-events
story: The owners of The Mart, East Linton, were initially given temporary permission to use the restored building for events in  but the Covid- outbreak saw the approval lapse.Now, they have applied for the right to hold a range of celebrations in the building, which they acknowledge was not built to ldquocontain high levels of sound.And East Lothian Council has given them the go-ahead to host events until the end of this year, while restricting how often they can have amplied music or sound.The Mart owners applied for the building, which sits in the centre of a restored site with a farm shop, cafe and market stalls, to be given Class  status.That would allow it to host events such as birthday parties, weddings, christenings and baby showers.There are also plans to hold community events such as gala day at the building and hold film nights.But issuing its approval of the change in use, council planners insisted it could not have nightly noisy events.They added as one of its conditions that ldquono events involving amplied music and or amplied speech shall fall on consecutivedays.A former animal auction mart, the hexagonal timber building was built in about  and is Category B listed.Applying for the change of use on behalf of The Mart, Urban Animation said: ldquoThe Mart business has invested heavily in bringing the building back into active use, after years ofdecay and listing on the Buildings at Risk Register.ldquoIt is a Listed Building which has been restoredto the highest standard and is once again a valued asset to the Mart site and East Lothian.ldquoIt isnow essential that the building is able to operate as a flexible space, accommodating a moreerse and productive range of new uses and activities.
